title: Inside a Billion Dollar Company Using AI to Supercharge Marketing & Sales

rawLines.text: No matter how smart, how fast these
tools get, brand is going to be the
reason why people trust your business,
come to you and return. It's the way
they feel on your site. They feel, you
know, talking to a sales rep or reading
a case study. It's defensible. It's your
point of view. And that ultimately is
going to be so critical in standing out
from the automated pack.
In this series, we're talking to
operators who are doing real innovative
work with AI within the enterprise.
Emily, thanks for joining us today.
You're the VP of growth at Vanta. Tell
us a little bit about what you do. We
are a trust management platform. So,
we're helping you automate compliance,
manage risk, improve trust in real time.
So, my team's in charge of pipeline at
Vanta. That's both pre and post sales.
So, that's making sure we're delivering
enough leads to our sales team to act on
and convert. And my team manages a lot
of the engines that go to market. So we
take a lot of the case studies, content
and messaging and deliver it on ads, our
life cycle marketing programs at events
and helps connect the journey for
customers from initial awareness of ant
problem to deal. So one of the biggest
shifts we're seeing um in B2B companies
is the trend of sales and marketing
coming together. Tell me a little bit
about what you're seeing there, how
that's uh played out at Vant, especially
where trust is really at the core of the
business. Yeah, absolutely. Well, to
your point, Vanta's product is trust.
So, we've got a product that people are
buying in security and we've got buyers
who are highly technical and really
understand the decisions they need to
make. And so, we have to make sure that
we're not creating a bunch of noise.
We're creating clarity. And to do that
well, marketing sales have to be tied at
the hip and build an engine that
delivers the right message at the right
time. What does that mean? Both in terms
of how your team is organized and also
now with AI tools, how you guys are
using them to to foster that bridge.
Yeah. So, an example of how we're seeing
this come to life. Let's take how we
work with leads. It used to be a
prospect would come to your site, they'd
land on a landing page, and they'd fill
out a form with their information, and
you'd get a bunch of fmographic
information that they've inputed. And
the marketing team would supply the
sales team with personalized content
that they could send out, but it was
more based on the persona because we
didn't know much about the user. And you
might have the sales team go on
LinkedIn, understand the tech stack that
the user has on their site and position
that a little bit more in a unique and
personalized way. But now we can do that
all with a click of a button. So we've
got tools like Clay, we've got tools
like Koala and Common Room that very
much are allowing us to get even more
and deeper information. And not just on
thermographic side. What's really cool
is that they're looking at hundreds of
different data points including
behavioral information. So you can
understand the intent behind the buyer,
where they are in their journey, if they
switched jobs recently. And so that's
giving us a level of depth of
understanding that we can then use to
really personalize their journey. Yeah.
So to double click on that, you've got
all these great intent signals that are
now being um harvested by AI. How do you
what do you do with those signals and
how do you make it still feel personal
to the buyer versus, you know, just
getting a a sort of spammed email with
the fields filled in with the
personalization? Yeah. Well, that is
very important. So first I highly
recommend you sit down and you outline
your sales journey uh with sales,
marketing and product and then AI tools
can very much be helpful at bringing
together all the data. So you're using
it in a unified way across that life
cycle. So a couple of examples of how
we're doing this. We've got Clay. It's
enriching our data. We're then taking
Clay and we're integrating that data
into our CMS, which happens to be web
flow, and we're updating our landing
page in live time with the information
we have that's relevant to the user.
That same information is then available
for our SDRs in their AIS SDR tools. So,
think Alice, think Reggie. That's
providing them information that they can
then craft into outreach and be very
personalized, but also in line with the
messages that marketing is sharing. And
even further, you can take that into
your website with conversational chat
and present the same data to your SDR
who's communicating live time with
individuals. And have you guys built out
the tooling to connect all those points
or is that sort of kind of happening
through humans? Like how are you able to
make sure that thread really flows
through? Great question. And go to
market operations is very much a very
big piece of this craft and it's
bringing the data and intelligent ways
together into our salesforce as well as
ensuring we're using similar tools for
enrichment and those tools can work with
other AI tools to build consistency in
the data across platforms and do you
like having multiple tools or would you
want it all to sort of be consolidated
into one system? I very much see the
future being that a CMO and a you know a
head of sales is orchestrating across
multiple tools but within one system.
Today that's not the case at the end of
the day. Yes, one simp one one system
would be simpler but these tools are so
powerful and being able to deliver
messages in a more personalized way and
faster and personalization and speed are
ultimately really critical levers for
conversion. And so they're having
tremendous impact on our team's
efficiency. And how do you guys, you
know, you're using all these tools,
there's AI in the background, some of
it's AI generated signals or content.
How do you know it's working? Really
strong feedback loops with your sales
team is critical. And that's meeting
with them in person and in structured
ways. But on top of that, we're using a
lot of tools to help us get those
insights. So on the qualitative side,
we're using Gong. And Gong is taking all
of our sales information and
conversations and then giving us
information on what points or
positioning are creating the most
objections or driving the most close
ones and that allows us to optimize our
positioning in more lifetime. If you had
to pick one thing that's really like
unlocked time, is there a particular
tool or like class of tools that you
would you would point to? So data
enrichment very much is where we're
finding the most value today because
it's able to give us not just so much
more depth but so much more depth live
time that we can react to. And if you
can know where you are in the buyer's
journey and tailor the right message to
the right time, you're ultimately going
to make it so much smoother for the
customer to go from curiosity to
conversion. And that's what we're trying
to do. Is there an area you wish there
was a tool that doesn't exist yet or
it's still too early? The whole class of
tools is still early, but it would be a
huge unlock for you and your team. On
the marketing side, we have been able to
craft a lot of assistance and GPTs that
allow us to not just do our work better
and craft narratives, but remind us of
all the tasks that we need to do around
a, you know, a given launch. And project
management tools are very helpful, but
you always learn and iterate in terms of
what's working to get 10% better. And I
have found that they are very successful
at producing content when provided the
right brand compass and they're very
good at reminding us of the tasks that
need to get done or the learnings we
need to follow up with. On the image
side, I don't yet feel that we're there
yet with the programs, but the
opportunity is clearly coming and the
improvements we've seen in these
platforms and their ability to create
images has been night and day and so I
expect in a few months time we'll be
able to use it. It sounds like your team
has built a bunch of these tools
internally. So are you just taking like
a chat and have built out specific
content generation through that written
content or have you found a tool that
does this that you pay for? Right now I
have found that it has worked best for
me when I'm building a GPT for my team.
And what's so important is that you put
in the context that it needs. It's
obviously going to do research on the
internet, but it needs the compass so
that ultimately you build consistency in
all your different touch points. What we
need to do to really get it to output
the right content is to give it guidance
for the different kinds of contents we
have. So a LinkedIn post is going to
have specific instructions. An email
post or email is going to have specific
instruction. A blog post, it's going to
look very different. So the more
guidance you give it and the more
information you give it in terms of
what's working, the better it's going to
iterate. That's so interesting that
you've you've built internally and there
isn't isn't a tool in the market that
really does that. But I as you as you
mentioned, maybe it is that context that
you you're able to provide it and and
maybe specific workflows that your GPT
is are being built around. Yeah. And
again, you know, there's a new tool
every day and we go in with such a
growth mindset. So I'm always
encouraging my team to go in and try
these new new tools and see where they
can get to and Vanta is creating a
budget to ensure that teams can go out
and test these tools and have that
growth. And maybe to bubble up a little
bit, if you look at your industry
overall, you've been in marketing for
quite a bit. How has the attitude
towards tools or budget for tools and
agency spend changed now, especially
with AI? Over time, every dollar needs
to get more efficient is the reality.
And that is the constant challenge for
marketers and it's the constant
challenges for companies and startups.
And so really thinking about how you can
use AI to help you get more efficient
but also do more. The ability of tools
to enable that workflow for us is going
to be such an enabler of efficiency. And
you know, one thing we we've chatted
about before is there are a class of
measurement tools and then there's the
the tools that take action on the
measurement. Where do you think we are
in terms of AI tooling for both
measurement and then sort of closing the
loop and doing something with that
measurement? Oh, I mean, you know, we're
right now working with a couple
different tools to improve our
attribution. And those tools look like
Cocky Stack or Dream Data. And they're
able to do a great job of measuring the
different touch points you have across
your go to market marketing and sales.
And they're very helpful at unboxing
what that journey looks like so you're
not guessing in the dark. But ultimately
with the changes in privacy and the
limitations on pixel and data sending,
it is becoming harder to understand what
that looks like. I think the real
opportunity for attribution tools is
different ways of measurement and
modeling that allow us to take in more
indifferent inputs to produce
expectations of output and that will
bring a lot of speed to businesses.
Everyone wants better measurement around
um around brand and how marketing spend
on brand is performing. Have you seen
any of that change with AI and these
measurement tools or do you think we
still have a ways ways to go especially
since content creation is still uh
getting getting just good enough to
start using no matter how smart how fast
these tools get brand is going to be the
reason why people trust your business
come to you and return it's the way they
feel on your site they feel you know
talking to a sales rep or reading a case
study it's defensible it's your point of
view and that ultimately is going to be
so critical in standing out from the
automated pack. So use brand as your
compass. Use it to inform how your
automation is operating and I promise
you that you will see it drives such a
better and seamless experience for your
prospects going from curiosity to
conversion. We're seeing it at Vant. Do
you think there's a way for AI to be
impacting your brand spend or brand
strategy? I absolutely think that AI is
going to enable us to get much more
personalized which is going to impact
the experience with the brand. At the
same time, I think with personalization
comes the expectation of white glove
experience. And so your customers are
going to want to make sure that human
touch is still there. How that comes to
life through community and other
elements that only really humans can do
today, I think is still going to be true
in a future state where AI is
influencing brand. And so make sure you
understand your northstar and your brand
center of gravity. Thinking ahead, what
do you think the marketing team is going
to look like in say 5 to 10 years? So
one for CMOs, their job is going to be
about building systems and
orchestration. They're going to be
deeply partnered with sales and product
and understanding what those systems
look like and they are going to still
define the brand, the ethics, and the
metrics and they're going to support
their team and AI working within that.
On the team side, I believe we're going
to see people become real experts in
their craft. They're going to understand
how to use these tools and operate at a
scale they themselves have never seen
before, which probably means less
agencies and more people that are really
skilled within the craft themselves. So,
one thing we've talked about is how many
specialists within marketing, so an
excellent performance marketer, will
often go off and start consulting and be
more of a contractor versus working
within a single company. Do you think
that shift towards specialization and
these experts in in brand content
performance marketing changes so there's
more people inhouse or do you think
people become more generalist with more
tools? Like how do you think that'll
look? I think it ultimately what will
become what is most efficient for
businesses as well as what's most
economical for the marketer. At the end
of the day, marketers love their craft.
They're as close as they can be to the
customer and so they're going to go to
brands and companies that align with
what they want to do. Being in more
control of your day-to-day tends to lend
itself to give you more ability to do
that and so likely we'll see more people
go off on their own, become experts in
their craft and support multiple
businesses in this way. It'll be more
economical for the business and the
marketer. Do you have any hot takes on
marketing, marketing and AI and the
future? So my hot take is the most
defensible things 10 years from now will
be your brand workflows that require
high trust and data. So what that means
in practice is we're going to see
consumers really seek out brands that
are able to give them human experiences.
They're going to be overloaded with
information that feels similar and what
feels like robots doing things for them.
And that's helpful, but at the end of
the day, we're human. We want
relationships. We want connection on the
workflow side. Over time, I think
everybody is going to start trusting
more of these bots and agents who are
doing these workflows, but there will be
things that are very complianceheavy or
healthy that people are going to
continue to want oversight on to ensure
that these agents are doing the right
thing and have the right ethics. And
then data becomes our most valuable
asset, right? The more data we have, the
more we can do and build with agents and
AI. And so having proprietary data is
going to give you an edge against
competitors and others in the market who
can build similar products. The magic
question is how you get that proprietary
data and how proprietary it's always the
magic question.

Great question. I very much see the future being that a CMO and a head of Sales is orchestrating across multiple tools but within one system. Today that's not the case at the end of the day. So data enrichment very much is where we're finding the most value today because it's able to give us not just so much more depth but so much more depth live time that we can react to. And if you can know where you are in the buyer's journey and tailor the right message to the right time, you're ultimately going to make it so much smoother for the customer to go from curiosity to conversion. And that's what we're trying to do.

The whole class of tools is still early, but it would be a huge unlock for you and your team. On the Marketing side, we have been able to craft a lot of assistance and GPTs that allow us to not just do our work better and craft narratives, but remind us of all the tasks that we need to do around a given launch. On the image side, I don't yet feel that we're there yet with the programs, but the opportunity is clearly coming and the improvements we've seen in these platforms and their ability to create images has been night and day, and so I expect in a few months time we'll be able to use it.

It sounds like your team has built a bunch of these tools internally. So are you just taking like a chat and have built out specific content generation through that written content or have you found a tool that does this that you pay for?

Right now I have found that it has worked best for me when I'm building a GPT for my team. And what's so important is that you put in the context that it needs. What we need to do to really get it to output the right content is to give it guidance for the different kinds of contents we have. So a LinkedIn post is going to have specific instructions. An email post or email is going to have specific instruction. A blog post, it's going to look very different. So the more guidance you give it and the more information you give it in terms of what's working, the better it's going to iterate.

That's so interesting that you've built internally and there isn't a tool in the market that really does that. But I, as you mentioned, maybe it is that context that you're able to provide it and maybe specific workflows that your GPT is are being built around.

Yeah. And again, you know, there's a new tool every day and we go in with such a growth mindset. So I'm always encouraging my team to go in and try these new tools and see where they can get to, and Vanta is creating a budget to ensure that teams can go out and test these tools and have that growth.

And maybe to bubble up a little bit, if you look at your industry overall, you've been in Marketing for quite a bit. How has the attitude towards tools or budget for tools and agency spend changed now, especially with AI?

Over time, every dollar needs to get more efficient is the reality. And that is the constant challenge for marketers and it's the constant challenges for companies and startups. And so really thinking about how you can use AI to help you get more efficient but also do more. The ability of tools to enable that workflow for us is going to be such an enabler of efficiency.

And you know, one thing we've chatted about before is there are a class of measurement tools and then there's the tools that take action on the measurement. Where do you think we are in terms of AI tooling for both measurement and then sort of closing the loop and doing something with that measurement?

Oh, I mean, you know, we're right now working with a couple different tools to improve our Attribution. And those tools look like Cocky Stack or Dream Data. And they're able to do a great job of measuring the different touch points you have across your go-to-market Marketing and Sales. And they're very helpful at unboxing what that journey looks like so you're not guessing in the dark. But ultimately with the changes in privacy and the limitations on pixel and data sending, it is becoming harder to understand what that looks like. I think the real opportunity for attribution tools is different ways of measurement and modeling that allow us to take in more indifferent inputs to produce expectations of output, and that will bring a lot of speed to businesses.

Everyone wants better measurement around brand and how Marketing spend on brand is performing. Have you seen any of that change with AI and these measurement tools or do you think we still have a ways to go, especially since content creation is still getting just good enough to start using?

No matter how smart, how fast these tools get, brand is going to be the reason why people trust your business, come to you, and return. It's the way they feel on your site. They feel, you know, talking to a sales rep or reading a case study. It's defensible. It's your point of view, and that ultimately is going to be so critical in standing out from the automated pack. So use brand as your compass. Use it to inform how your automation is operating, and I promise you that you will see it drives such a better and seamless experience for your prospects going from curiosity to conversion. We're seeing it at Vanta.

Do you think there's a way for AI to be impacting your brand spend or brand strategy?

I absolutely think that AI is going to enable us to get much more personalized, which is going to impact the experience with the brand. At the same time, I think with personalization comes the expectation of white-glove experience. And so your customers are going to want to make sure that human touch is still there. How that comes to life through community and other elements that only really humans can do today, I think is still going to be true in a future state where AI is influencing brand. And so make sure you understand your North Star and your brand center of gravity.

Thinking ahead, what do you think the Marketing team is going to look like in say 5 to 10 years?

So one for CMOs, their job is going to be about building systems and orchestration. They're going to be deeply partnered with Sales and product and understanding what those systems look like, and they are going to still define the brand, the ethics, and the metrics, and they're going to support their team and AI working within that. On the team side, I believe we're going to see people become real experts in their craft. They're going to understand how to use these tools and operate at a scale they themselves have never seen before, which probably means less agencies and more people that are really skilled within the craft themselves.

So, one thing we've talked about is how many specialists within Marketing, so an excellent performance marketer, will often go off and start consulting and be more of a contractor versus working within a single company. Do you think that shift towards specialization and these experts in brand, content, performance Marketing changes so there's more people in-house or do you think people become more generalist with more tools? Like how do you think that'll look?

I think it ultimately what will become what is most efficient for businesses as well as what's most economical for the marketer. At the end of the day, marketers love their craft. They're as close as they can be to the customer, and so they're going to go to brands and companies that align with what they want to do. It'll be more economical for the business and the marketer.
